body.title: Compiler part 2.2 - Type analysis and Code geneation!
body.description: So in the last blog post, we created the parsing module that generated our AST! Today we will be generating the internal IR, code generation (what we did in part 1, but now based on our IR!), and then also adding those shell commands we used afterward to the compiler itself.

children.value: Compiler part 2.2 - Type analysis and Code geneation!
So in the last blog post, we created the

module that generated our AST! Today we will be generating the internal IR, code generation (what we did in part 1, but now based on our IR!), and then also adding those shell commands we used afterward to the compiler itself.
The full code for this post can be found at
This step is basically "figure out what everything is!", we basically apply a bunch of rules to give every part of our compiler a type
This might sound hard, but it is rather simple, code might be something along the lines of

props.code:
if plus.left == int a&& plus.right == int {plus.result = int}
else {error(...)}

children.value: Our IR will contain type information in contrast to the AST, we could encode this using fields (and we will for dynamic types like structs.). While the AST represents what the code looks like, the IR should represent what the code
This also gives us a benefit from the rust compiler, We can't for example construct an

type print and give it a String by accident!
This ensures we do the type analysis correctly.
Now we can do some type analyzing, with so few instructions it is rather simple:
So why this enum? Well consider
, we don't know what the type should be when we walk an expression, so what is the return type? This is one of those times you would want a union, but in Rust, we shall use more enums!
Again here we use the power of abstraction! Very simple so far, but even with more complex rules this will stay simple

This should also be really clear, and a bit similar to the parsing. And in a way, we are just "parsing" the AST into an IR.
Now that we have this let's try to print it out!
you should get something like the following:
Now we are gonna turn this IR into some actual code! Using
the same way we did in Part 1.

You will see a lot of the same structs here, with the addition of the fpm, it is the optimizer!
We don't have to write it ourselves! So instead of worrying about if we should optimize stuff, just don't first and see if LLVM does it for you, if it does, then great less work for us! So always try the simple stuff first, like we will output every variable on the heap, but LLVM will promote them to registers where it works.
We also have this so the Int width in

is easier to work (this means we are restricted to these options.)
Now we can actually do some code gen:
// In the future we will have functions, for now put everything in main()
We need to add the libc functions definitions we will be using, we will be using more in the future so stay tuned

The most complex part here is the print statement, but it should look very similar to what we did in part 1! We just do some conditional selecting of the formatting string, so the constructed call might look like

We can now save this, and here is a small optimization I will do! In the last post we used the text version of LLVM IR, but there is a bytecode version that will take up less space and be more efficient!

And yes we do generate the output twice if we have the debug flag set, but it is a debug flag, it doesn't really matter.
We also run optimization in this part because we already have the compiler options!
Now we just have to call this from our
function, but one question, in what file should we save the result? well, here the
crate will help us! it will allow us to create temporary files for use during compiling!

props.code: cargo add temp-file

children.value: then we can generate and use our temporary file
Now we need to compile this LLVM IR down to a binary, to do this we will spawn subprocesses of
To do this we will create some helper functions!
These two functions will let us search the
env variable for the command line tools we need to invoke!
We then use these to do our 2 steps in compiling from an LLVM ir to a binary
"Clang or gcc not found on path"
Then we can use these in the
let's update our Run code to generate an output file and run it
if we now just run our script,
being printed on the terminal! Congratulations! We now have a fully working compiler
Just one last thing I want to add before we wrap up, add a
command, what use is a compiler if we can't save our binary?
we can now test our new command.

props.code:
cargo run -- build test.viv test 
./test

children.value: So today we made a complete compiler, fair enough it does only support printing numbers, but my god wasn't it fun! So much learning, if you want you can go ahead and play with this, try changing the syntax, and maybe even add more features yourself?

In the next post we will create the next obvious feature booleans!
... wait really? booleans? we don't even have operators!
And yhe you are right, it is a bit unusual, our first operator will be
, but there is a good reason. I want to start writing integration tests, and for that, we need
But we will do that next! If you have any questions feel free to leave them in the comments below.
